questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the physiological jaundice in neonates is true?
questions.solution:
• Most neonates develop visible jaundice due to elevation of unconjugated bilirubin concentration during their first week. This common condition is called Physiological jaundice. It lasts for 5 days in term infants & 7 days in preterm infants.
  • It does not require any treatment & disappears spontaneously.

Non-physiologic Neonatal Jaundice Criteria

  • Neonatal Jaundice in first 24 hours of life
  • Serum Bilirubin rises > 5 mg/dl in the first 24 hours
  • Direct Bilirubin (conjugated) >2mg/dl

Term Infant

  • Serum Bilirubin >17 mg/dl
  • Neonatal Jaundice persists longer than 1 week

Exception: Breast Feeding Jaundice may persist >1 month

Preterm Infant

  • Serum Bilirubin >15 mg/dl
  • Jaundice persists longer than 2 weeks

Exception: Breast Feeding Jaundice may persist >1 month

Topic: Neonatal Physiological jaundice

Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of newborn care, SA edition, pagenumber. 347

questions.text: Parents of a 3-week-old newborn is counselled by the neonatologist that the child has physiological anemia of newborn. Which of the following criteria is not a feature in this condition?
questions.solution:
Physiologic Anemia of Infancy

  • Hemoglobin drops to low point at age 6 to 8 weeks
  • Erythropoietin nadir drops Hemoglobin
  • Term Infants: Hemoglobin drops to 9-11 g/dl
  • Preterm Infants: Hemoglobin drops to 7-9 g/dl

Topic: Physiological anemia of infancy

Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of newborn care, SA edition, , page number:217

questions.text: A newborn is admitted to NICU with history of mother having positive vaginal culture for Chlamydia. Which of the following sample must be acquired from the newborn to diagnose/rule out chlamydial infection in the child?
questions.solution:
• About 70% of baby born to positive chlamydial infection develop conjunctivitis at day 5 of life so sample taken for diagnosis is conjunctival.
  • Chlamydial infection is most common cause of conjunctivitis in newborn.
  • Chlamydial infection causes watering discharge form eye (unlike purulent discharge in Gonococcal).

Topic: Chlamydia

Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of newborn care, SA edition, page number:460

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with 30% FiO2 and continue monitoring
Bag and mask ventilation with 100% FiO2 and chest compression
Bag and mask ventilation with 100% FiO2 and epinephrine administration
O2 via nasal cannula and skin-skin contact with mother

questions.text: A 31-year-old, gravida 1 para 0 woman vaginally delivers a 33-week estimated gestational age neonate at home. Upon arrival of emergency medical services, the neonate is grey and apneic. The heart rate is 70 beats/min. The neonate has been dried, stimulated, and suctioned without improvement. Of the following, the next BEST intervention is?
questions.solution:
• Bag-valve mask ventilation is the priority in newborns who need cardiorespiratory support after birth.
  • A rise in heart rate is the most important indicator of effective ventilation and response to resuscitative interventions.
  • Chest compressions are provided if there is a poor heart rate response to ventilation after appropriate ventilation is instituted.

Topic: Neonatal resuscitation

Reference: Neonatal resuscitation program guidelines, AAP- 2022

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to you with a history of recurrent episodes of pneumonia. He has had multiple skin abscesses, which have usually resolved with antibiotics in the past, although sometimes they have needed to be drained. On physical examination, his liver and spleen are enlarged. He also has an enlarged cervical lymph node that is warm, red, fluctuant, and tender to the touch. Initial laboratory evaluation shows low hemoglobin and hematocrit. Which of the following investigation will be most helpful?
questions.solution:
• This scenario presents a child with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) and highlights the differential diagnosis of a child with recurrent pulmonary infections.
  • CGD is characterized by recurrent, often severe bacterial (most frequently catalase positive) and fungal infections (most frequent in lungs, skin, lymph nodes, and liver), and granuloma formation.
  • It is caused by defects in phagocyte nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase.
  • The initial evaluation for CGD is a neutrophil function test—dihydrorhodamine (DHR)123.
  • Abnormal finding should be confirmed with genotyping. While the nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) is a simple screening test, it has largely been replaced by the DHR, which is a more quantitative assay and is now more readily accessible.

Topic: Chronic granulomatous disease

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 1139

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is suspected to be having JIA. Which of the following is not expected to be seen in the child?
questions.solution:
The clinical features in JIA:

  • Oligoarticular:
    • involving ≤4 joints within the 1st 6 months of disease onset.
  • Polyarticular:
    • inflammation of ≥5 joints in both upper and lower extremities.
  • Rheumatoid nodules:
    • on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, spine, and over the Achilles tendons.
  • Micrognathia reflects chronic temporomandibular joint disease.
  • sJIA is characterized by arthritis, fever, rash, and prominent visceral involvement, including hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and serositis (pericarditis). The evanescent salmon-colored lesions, classic for sJIA, are linear or circular and are most commonly distributed over the trunk and proximal extremities.
  • Koebner phenomenon, a cutaneous hypersensitivity in which classic lesions are brought on by superficial trauma, is often present.

Topic: Juvenile inflammatory arthritis

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:1258

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common anomaly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia?
questions.solution:
• Diaphragmatic Hernia is defined as a communication between abdominal & thoracic cavities with or without abdominal contents in thorax.
  • Females are affected more than males.
  • More common on left side and is posterolateral.
  • Associated anomalies may be seen 30% of cases CNS lesions, esophageal atresia, omphalocele and CVS lesions. Most cases are sporadic.
  • Cardiac anomalies are most commonly associated.

Topic: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 894

questions.text: A 6-year-old had fever for 7 days. She has erythema of palms, cervical lymphadenopathy, conjunctival congestion, and lip cracking. She is suspected to be having Kawasaki disease. What should be the first line of management for the kid?
questions.solution:
• Patients with acute KD should be treated with 2 g/kg of IVIG and high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day divided q6h) within 10 days of disease onset and ideally as soon as possible after diagnosis.
  • Corticosteroids have been trialed as primary therapy with the first dose of IVIG in hopes of improving coronary outcomes.

Topic: Kawasaki disease

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number: 1315

choices.text: Very long chain fatty acid level

questions.text: Newborn screening in a 4-day-old female neonate detects hyperphenylalaninemia. He is put on phenylalanine-free diet and laboratory studies to include red blood cell dihydropteridine reductase assay and urine pterin analysis. Of the following, the additional supportive laboratory investigation to support the diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis in the case is phenylketonuria. To reinforce the diagnosis serum amino acid levels can be done to check for phenylalanine levels.
  • Phenylketonuria is a metabolic disorder caused by the enzymatic deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase that, without dietary restriction of phenylalanine implemented in early infancy, will result in irreversible and profound intellectual disability in most children.
  • Individuals with untreated phenylketonuria present with a mousy body odor, developmental regression, light skin and hair, eczema, seizures, and irreversible intellectual disability.

Topic: Phenylketonuria

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number:695

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who noticed that the left side of his mouth has started to droop over the past several days. In addition, he is unable to close his left eye completely and says that it is burning. Review of systems reveals a cold approximately two weeks ago and recent decreased taste sensation. There is left eye ptosis and mild erythema of the left conjunctiva. His smile is asymmetrical on the left. Which of the following virus is not responsible for this among following?
questions.solution:
• This patient has Bell's palsy, a postinfectious allergic or immune demyelinating facial neuritis. The most common cause of acute onset facial nerve palsy in children has in the past been acute otitis media. However, Lyme disease (choice B) may be a more common cause in endemic areas than otitis media. 10% retain mild facial weakness and 5% have permanent severe facial weakness. Therapeutic intervention should include daily and nocturnal eye lubricants to protect the cornea from drying.
  • Other infectious causes of acute peripheral facial palsy include cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus (choice A), adenovirus (choice C), rubella virus, mumps, influenza B , and coxsackievirus.
  • Measles (choice D) is associated with subacute sclerosing panencephalitis, a chronic encephalitis of the central nervous system manifested by progressively bizarre behavior and decline in cognitive function.

Topic: Bells palsy

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number: 1671

questions.text: What is the most common cause of a gray patch of the lumbo-sacral region in neonate?
questions.solution:
• Dermal melanocytosis (mongolian spot) is a benign melanocytic lesion that occurs in more than 90% of African-American infants, more than 80% of Asian infants, 70% of Hispanic infants, and close to 10% of Caucasian infants.
  • The lesions appear as gray, blue-black, or brown patches, most commonly over the lumbosacral back and buttocks.
  • Most are present at birth and fade in the first 2 to 3 years of life, although occasionally they persist into adulthood.

Topic: Dermal melanocytosis

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, , page number:3454

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presents to the emergency department with 24 hours of progressive limp and low-grade fever. His mother reports that he was running on the grass in the front yard 2 days ago and fell, subsequently complaining of shin pain on the left side. Examination reveals a tender, swollen left knee. The patient is holding the knee in flexion and refuses to move it. Of the following, the most sensitive finding to indicate joint space infection is?
questions.solution:
• An elevated C-reactive protein is the most sensitive indicator of infection among the choices.
  • Radiographs in acute joint infection might display soft tissue swelling or a joint effusion, but they lack sensitivity.
  • The most sensitive radiologic procedure is an MRI of the affected area.
  • MRI can also assist in localizing the infection extent and determining the presence of adjacent osteomyelitis.

Topic: Infective arthritis

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:3676

questions.text: A 6-week-old girl is noted to have multiple annular, erythematous, scaly plaques on the head and neck. On physical examination, a heart rate of 40 beats/minute is noted. These findings are most likely the result of which of the following complications during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• The patient has cutaneous lesions consistent with neonatal lupus, supported by cardiac findings of severe bradycardia likely due to congenital heart block.
  • Maternal IgG (anti-Ro/La) antibodies are passed via the placenta to the fetus, causing annular plaques, which may be associated with congenital heart block, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, Coombs-positive hemolytic anemia, and/or elevated serum transaminases.
  • Although complete congenital heart block is permanent, all other associated signs and symptoms of neonatal lupus are transient and generally resolve over a period of 4–6 months.
  • Up to 90–95% of all cases of complete congenital heart block are due to neonatal lupus.
  • A unique radiologic finding of neonatal lupus is stippling of the epiphyses (chondrodysplasia punctata).
  • The majority of mothers giving birth to infants with neonatal lupus and congenital heart block are asymptomatic and require evaluation to confirm their own diagnosis. Some go on to develop Sjögren syndrome rather than systemic lupus erythematosus.

Neonatal lupus - erythematous scaly plaques on head

Topic: Maternal lupus

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:1279

questions.text: A newborn who was delivered at home is brought to your office 30 hours after birth. She was born at 40 weeks' gestation to a 42-year-old primi mother by uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. The maternal prenatal screening was normal. The maternal history was remarkable only for chronic hypertension. The newborn has been exclusively breastfeeding since birth. Vital signs include temperature of 37°C, HR 140 beats/min, and RR 50 breaths/min. Physical examination reveals a quiet, slightly ruddy newborn weighing 2,400 g. There is jaundice of the face and chest, periodic breathing with rare 20 second pauses, slightly decreased tone, and listlessness. The mother describes her newborn as being very quiet for the past 12 hours. Out of the following the most important investigation to establish the diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Small-for-gestational age (SGA) infants are at increased risk for hypoglycemia because of insufficient hepatic and skeletal muscle glycogen stores. Some affected infants have superimposed hyperinsulinemia.
  • SGA infants with concurrent intrauterine growth restriction have increased perinatal morbidity and mortality.
  • SGA infants should be monitored for hypoglycemia for the first 24 hours after birth.

Topic: SGA

Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of newborn care, SA edition, page number:910

questions.text: A mother brings her 12-month-old son to the office for a follow-up visit after he developed hives from eating his first bite of peanut butter. He was seen by an allergist and was diagnosed with a peanut allergy. His mother is very concerned that he may be allergic to other foods. What are the most common foods that cause allergic reactions in childhood?
questions.solution:
• The most common foods causing allergy in childhood in descending order are milk > egg > peanut > tree nuts > shellfish > fish > wheat > soy.
  • It is important to tell patients and families that similar foods may cross react. For example, a child with a cashew allergy may be allergic to other tree nuts.
  • Testing for allergies to similar foods may be indicated before these foods are introduced into the diet.

Topic: Food allergy

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number:1288

questions.text: A term 3-day-old infant was born through meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Following aspiration of meconium, the infant developed respiratory failure. On current examination, he has a systolic murmur and a loud second heart sound. His chest radiograph reveals a hyperlucent background in addition to patchy areas of opacity. Despite the use of ventilator (including HFO), the respiration worsens. Which of the following treatment options is most likely to be effective in addressing the underlying pathophysiology?
questions.solution:
• The infant in this vignette developed persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) secondary to meconium aspiration syndrome.
  • PPHN is characterized by persistently elevated pulmonary vascular tone causing intrapulmonary or extrapulmonary right-to-left shunting.
  • High-frequency oscillation is being used in this vignette to improve lung inflation.
  • Techniques to reduce pulmonary vascular tone include avoiding hypercarbia, hypoxia, and acidosis. Another therapy is inhaled nitric oxide, a selective pulmonary vasodilator.
  • Inhaled nitric oxide has become an important therapy in the management of PPHN.
  • Diuretics that block transporters in the nephron (chlorthiazide to block the Na + –Cl − symporter or furosemide to block the Na + –K + –2Cl − cotransporter) have a limited role in PPHN.
  • Opiates, which activate mu opioid receptors, may be used for sedating patients who have difficulty tolerating high-frequency ventilation but are not specifically therapeutic in PPHN.

Topic: Meconium aspiration syndrome

Reference: Cloherty and Starks manual of newborn care, SA edition, page number:462

questions.text: A 1-week-old girl present with rocker bottom feet, overlapping fingers, clenched fist and multiple other dysmorphic features. Chromosomal analysis shown below. Which of the following is the most common cause of death in these children?
questions.solution:
• Central apnea is the most common cause of death in Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome).

Features of Edward syndrome

  • Low birthweight, closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th, narrow hips with limited abduction, short sternum, rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly, prominent occiput, micrognathia, cardiac and renal malformations, and intellectual disability.
  • ~92% of children die in the first year; with full support ~25% may survive 1 yr. Survivors have significant neurodevelopmental delay.

Topic: Edward syndrome

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, pagenumber. 659

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy develops acute onset of high spiking fevers, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and purpura; he has been diagnosed with systemic Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) since early childhood treated with anti inflammatory drugs. You suspect macrophage activating syndrome (MAS). Of the following, the BEST test that distinguishes MAS from a flare of the primary disease is
questions.solution:
• The most important indicators of MAS include a falling platelet count, extreme hyperferritinemia, increased liver enzymes, falling leukocyte count, persistent, continuous fever ≥38°C, falling ESR, hypofibrinogenemia, and hypertriglyceridemia.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by bone marrow biopsy demonstrating hemophagocytosis

Topic: Macrophage activating syndrome

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number 1262

questions.text: A 6-year-old male is brought to your office 10 days after the onset of a cough and low-grade fever. On examination, his temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse 100 beats/min, respirations 22/min, and O2 saturation 94%. He has diffuse wheezes on auscultation of his chest. His WBC count is 9800cellls /micro L with a slight left shift. His C-reactive protein level is mildly elevated and a chest radiograph reveals an interstitial infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of pneumonia in children ages 5 - 15 is Mycoplasma pneumoniae, which is sensitive to macrolides.
  • The low-grade temperature, borderline WBC count, and lack of a markedly elevated C-reactive protein do not suggest pneumococcal disease.
  • Wheezing is characteristic of both viral and mycoplasmal disease.
  • Respiratory syncytial virus is the most common cause of pneumonia in children age 4 months to 4 years.
  • A 6-year-old is more likely to have mycoplasmal disease.

Topic: Mycoplasma

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number. 1611

questions.text: A 16-month-old girl is evaluated in ER for a rash and difficulty breathing. She was in her usual state of good health until, while eating a peanut butter and jelly sandwich, she suddenly developed a cough, swelling of her lips, and a rash. On physical examination, she has a heart rate of 140 beats/min, respiratory rate of 30 breaths/min, blood pressure of 70/40 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 82% in room air. She has swelling of her lips, an urticarial rash, and diffuse wheezing on chest auscultation. Which of the following best describes the allergic reaction type?
questions.solution:
• These findings are consistent with anaphylaxis, a type 1, IgE-mediated allergic reaction.
  • Type 2 reactions are antibody driven (e.g., autoimmune hemolytic diseases).
  • Type 3 reactions are caused by antigen-antibody complexes (e.g., drug induced serum sickness).
  • Type 4 reactions are cell mediated and often described as a delayed reaction (eg, proctocolitis in infants).
  • The most common food allergies include milk, soy, and egg; peanut, seafood, wheat, and tree nuts account for most of the remaining allergens.
  • Serum IgE levels or skin prick testing are the tests of choice for diagnosing IgE-mediated allergies.

Topic: Anaphylaxis

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number:1229

questions.text: A newborn girl develops a perinatal blistering skin rash that then gives rise to a swirling pattern of skin hyperpigmentation. Her mother exhibits the same syndrome. What is this condition's pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
• The child shows symptoms of incontinentia pigmenti.
  • It is an X linked dominant disorder where her mother is also suffering from it. Males die in utero.

Typical skin manifestations of Incontinentia Pigmenti distributed along Blaschko’s lines

Stage 1: Vesicobullous stage

Stage 2: Verrucous stage

Stage 3: Hyperpigmented stage

Stage 4: Atrophic/ hypopigmented stage

Topic: Incontinentia pigmenti

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:3159

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents for treatment of shiny, pink papules on the face. They were noted at age 6 years. Neither pustules nor comedones are seen on physical exam. What is the best next step?
questions.solution:
• Angiofibromas looking like shiny, pink papules are present on the nose and malar region of this child with tuberous sclerosis.
  • A clue is the absence of comedones helps in distinguishing angiofibromas from acne.

Topic: Angiofibroma

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:2476

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is seen for a health supervision visit. Her parents are concerned because their daughter can bend backward at the elbows and knees to a degree that seems unnatural and she is "double-jointed." They want to make sure that it is safe for her to participate in sports. The girl is active in sports without pain or limitations. On physical examination, the girl demonstrates 15 degrees of elbow extension and 15 degrees of knee extension bilaterally. She is able to touch her palms to the floor without bending her knees but does not have signs of increased joint mobility in her hands or wrists. The remainder of her physical examination findings are normal. Next best step of management is?
questions.solution:
• Joint hypermobility that is not associated with pain or activity limitation is a normal finding in school-aged children.
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, hypermobility type, describes individuals with joint hypermobility, arthralgias, and/or atraumatic joint dislocations, and other criteria, such as skin hyperextensibility, striae, and atrophic scarring.
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, hypermobility type, is diagnosed clinically.

Topic: Ehler Danlos syndrome

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition., page number:2618

questions.text: A 9 month old infant has developed fever and had an episode of febrile seizure. He was admitted in the hospital. The next day fever subsided and rash appeared on chest and abdomen. It is maculo-papular erythematous in nature. What can be most probable cause among the following?
questions.solution:
• In this question, infant had develop rash on first day of fever & distribution of rash is in favor of chickenpox, or varicella.

Mnemonic for Day of appearance of rash in a febrile patient is

  • Very Sick Person Must Take Double Tablets
  • Very - Varicella (day 1)
  • Sick - Scarlet fever (day 2)
  • Person - Pox-small pox (day 3)
  • Must - Measles (day 4)
  • Take - Typhus (day 5)
  • Double - Dengue (day 6)
  • Tablets - Typhoid (day 7)
  • In varicella, Child develop fever with rash. Rash are macular, maculo-papular, vesicular (pleomorphic). Distribution is usually centripetal.
  • Complications are more seen in immunocompromised child. These are thrombocytopenia, Hematuria, GI Bledding, Encephalitis, Pneumonia.

Topic: Varicella

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:1713

choices.text: Ceftriaxone for resident who intubated the child in PICU
High resolution chromosomal study if bacterial infections are recurrent

questions.text: An infant admitted with sepsis has a gram stain of the blood that shows intracellular and extracellular gram-negative diplococci. What is the appropriate next step among the following?
questions.solution:
• The child is suffering from infection by Neisseria Meningitidis. Ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in the patients.
  • The close contacts with the patient who had exposure to the respiratory secretions like intubation, must get post exposure prophylaxis. Ceftriaxone is drug of choice for PEP.
  • Respiratory isolation (choice B) may be discontinued after 24 hours of appropriate antibiotic therapy
  • Terminal complement studies (not high-resolution chromosomal studies, choice C) are ordered for patients with recurrent disease to rule out complement deficiencies, as these patients are more susceptible to meningococcal disease.
  • The meningococcal vaccine (choice D) is given to those patients who are without a spleen, are functionally asplenic (sickle cell), have a terminal complement deficiency, are living in a dormitory environment, or are in the midst of an epidemic.

Topic: Menningococcal meningitis

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, page number:1476
